title.rendered: I Went to San Diego Comic Con—Here’s What Happened: Part 2

content.rendered:
San Diego Comic Con (SDCC) is an event catered to the fans. This is because no movie or TV show would be possible without the fans. It is the fans who truly determine the success of any show or film.
 
Behind every view or audience number is a person. Look at MARVEL—the franchise struck the landing with Avengers: Endgame as it ended the cycle of films. Without fans all around the world purchasing their tickets to see Avengers: Endgame, it wouldn’t have become the highest grossing movie of all time, crossing $2.7902 billion at the global box office. Or, look at HBO with the network setting records for the TV world with their hit show Game of Thrones. Without fans worldwide tuning their televisions to the HBO channel to watching the series finale, “The Bells,” from start to finish, it wouldn’t have snagged 19.3 million sets of eyeballs.
 
 
That said, SDCC is a way for such franchises like Marvel Studios, The CW, ABC, CBS, NBC, and Amazon Prime, to celebrate the fans. Comic-Con celebrates every kind of fan through a wide array of pop culture media over four days every July. With about 135,000 people in attendance, panels were hosted by industry professionals to announce and preview new series and films, to educate fans about various aspects of media creation, and to reminisce about the previous season of a TV show while also discussing the up and coming season of said show. In addition, there were dozens of autograph signings from the casts of IT, The 100, Supergirl, Legacies, Game of Thrones, Westworld, His Dark Materials, MARVEL’S Agents of S.H.I.E.L.D., Riverdale, and so many more! Also, there were many off-site events, including Petco Park Interactive Zone, Amazon Prime Video Experience (showcasing The Boys, The Expanse and Carnival Row), HBO’s Watchmen Experience, ScareDiego, Team Coco House Stand-up shows, Conan at SDCC, Kitties and Coffee for Comic-Con, FYE Pop-up Shop, AMC’s Dead Quarters, NBC’s The Good Place, Superstore, and Brooklyn Nine-Nine activations, and more around the Gaslamp and convention center, which often create some fans’ best SDCC memories. Moreover, fans have countless opportunities to get their groove on at the best after parties, including READY PARTY ONE: A Most Excellent SDCC 2019 Experience, THE UPSIDE DOWN!, SDCC 2019 Thursday Night Party with NERDIST, Comic Con Themed Bar Crawl, AWESOME MIXER Vol. 2 and more. Fans also have the chance to roam the exhibit hall and artist alley located in the San Diego Convention Center to buy different merchandise. Such booths in the exhibit hall include HASBRO, FUNKO, MARVEL, BOOM! Studios, Monogram International Inc., and UCC Distributing. Lastly, many attendees also enjoy cosplaying as their favorite characters, often stopping to take pictures with people who are fans of such characters.
 
 
Despite this year being my fifth year attending SDCC, I’ve never grown bored at the convention, but rather drop dead exhausted from trying to do everything. FOMO is a real thing at Comic-Con, but at some point, you must accept you can’t do everything. Nonetheless, I was there to experience the 50th Anniversary of SDCC (even if it was a small portion), enabling me to give you in-depth coverage on the ground about certain events, which include plenty of highs, but also a few lows.
 
Preview Night (Wednesday):
I joined my friends in line at the exhibit hall around 3 p.m. When the exhibit hall opened at 6, we were released into the convention hall. Walking/running (it depends on who you ask, I personally say I was walking, but….) to the ABC booth (Booth #4245), I noticed there was a huge line already there, which could only mean one thing—exhibitors. Exhibitors can access the exhibit hall before any attendees. However, that means they can start lining up at any booth at any time to get any of the first come, first serve signings or merchandise. It’s not fair, but it is what it is. So, basically, I should have been one of the first few people in line, but I wasn’t since these exhibitors had lined up probably around 8:45 a.m. As a result, I didn’t get the signing I wanted—MARVEL’S Agents of S.H.I.E.L.D. Instead, I got the autograph ticket for The Rookie singing because you know…Nathan Fillion.
 
 
Immediately after I went to the DC and Warner Brothers booth (Booth #4545) as TV Guide magazine once again teamed with Warner Brothers Television to create and distribute one of fans’ favorite swag items during Comic-Con—the annual TV Guide Magazine Comic-Con special edition magazines. Since my first Comic-Con, I have gone to the booth on preview night to grab all all four sets of collective covers, thus making the act almost a tradition now. This year the main cover (and also my favorite) was “Powerhouse,” which featured more than 100 series stars from The 100, Arrow, Batwoman, Black Lightning, Chilling Adventures of Sabrina, DC’s Legends of Tomorrow, Doom Patrol, The Flash, Katy Keene, Krypton, Legacies, Lucifer, Manifest, Pennyworth, Riverdale, Stargirl, Supergirl, Swamp Thing, Titans, Veronica Mars and Roswell, New Mexico, and more!
 
The other three covers include Riverdale’s Lili Reinhart, Cole Sprouse, Camila Mendes, KJ Apa, Madelaine Petsch, Casey Cott, Vanessa Morgan, Ashleigh Murray, and Charles Melton, Supernatural’s Jared Padalecki, Alexander Calvert, Jensen Ackles, and Misha Collins, and Batwoman’s Ruby Rose.
 
 
Later that evening, I decided to go find the Loungfly booth. My friend who was standing in line with me earlier had gotten the Avengers: Infinity War tote from them last year. So, of course, that was what she was using to carry her things. And after having three hours to stare at it, I couldn’t not get something from the pop culture accessories brand who makes adorable bags, wallets, and more. So, of course, I decided to find them at Booth #5248 as I couldn’t miss some of the cutest accessories on the show floor. At the booth, I got the MARVEL’s Avengers: Endgame backpack for $65.
Thursday:
 
Around 5:00 a.m., I joined my friends— some of whom got in line around 4 a.m.— in the Everything Else line. Being one of the first people to be let into the exhibit hall, I quickly walked, because you can’t run! They literally say that phrase over and over on the overhead speakers. to the ABC booth (Booth #4245) to grab an autograph ticket for MARVEL’S Agents of S.H.I.E.L.D. signing. This time, I was actually able to snag one since most of the exhibitors got theirs yesterday; therefore, I was in the front of the line. Thank God!
 
Since the entire process took about 20 minutes, I decided to try for another signing in the Sails Pavilion. After all, they wouldn’t start drawing until after everyone in the general line in the exhibit hall had done so. This is because this line is moved inside the Sails Pavilion at a certain point. Thus, blocking the area to draw any exclusive signings—basically it’s a fire hazard to have both things happening at the same time. So, I immediately left to go line up in the Exclusive Signings line in the Sails Pavilion. Around 9:30 a.m., they let us in the Autograph Area in the Sails Pavilion. Luckily, on my first try, I drew the winning autograph ticket for The Order.
 
Immediately after my friends and I got in line to draw a ticket for the Van Helsing signing because we had nothing else to do. Fortunately, one of my friends drew a winning ticket; however, those who didn’t weren’t upset as we didn’t truly care. After all, we were just killing time so that we wouldn’t arrive too early to AMC’s DeadQuarters. That said, although the off-site opened up at 11 a.m., we arrived there around 10:40 a.m and about 50 people were already in line.
 
Upon getting closer and closer to the gates we learned that The Walking Dead and Fear the Walking Dead autograph signing tickets were being given out practically on a first come first serve basis. Those who donated with either food or a monetary donation had the chance to draw a ticket out of a bag. Workers told me you had a 50/50 chance, yet almost everyone who donated got a winning ticket. Plus, if you donated twice, you could draw from the bag twice, thus increasing your chances of winning. This means if you won on your first try for let’s say The Walking Dead, you could try drawing for Fear the Walking Dead. Ultimately, you could easily win both autograph signings, which is what I believe happened for most people. Therefore, winning tickets went extremely fast—so fast that by the time we got to the front of the line all tickets were gone. Now, this was extremely upsetting as AMC has NEVER given out their autograph tickets like this. It’s always been insanely hard to obtain the winning ticket since in the past you’ve had to be chosen via social media by posting various things things or picking a ticket out of bag that I estimate had a ratio of ten loser tickets for every winning ticket (it would take almost two days of people constantly drawing until all winning tickets were gone). If I would have known this information ahead of time, I wouldn’t have fooled around earlier and had gotten to the off-site ASAP.
 
 
When I finally walked through the gates, I found myself immersed in scenes from both AMC’s hit shows, The Walking Dead and Fear the Walking Dead. The off-site included the Winter Escape from the Season 9 finale of The Walking Dead as well as an elaborate treehouse and plane crash site inspired by the Season 5 storylines in Fear the Walking Dead. Additionally, I was able to demo the much-anticipated VR game, The Walking Dead Onslaught.
 
That afternoon, I did a signing with Lev Grossman, creator of The Magicians and Lilah Sturges (The Magicians, Lumberjanes) at Boom! Studios (Booth #2229). At the award-winning publisher’s booth, attendees had the opportunity to meet and get signatures from comic creators like Dan Mora, Lev Grossman, and Matt Kindt, plus voice actor Olivia Olson (Adventure Time) and actor Karen Ashley (Mighty Morphin’ Power Rangers), and more celebrities. This year’s exclusives included The Magicians: Alice’s Story 10th Year Anniversary Exclusive Variant Hardcover Edition—a limited edition hardcover with exclusive variant cover celebrates the 10 Year Anniversary of Lev Grossman’s bestselling series, The Magicians for $40. I actually didn’t even plan on doing this signing. I had ventured over to the booth to look at the exclusive book since I saw it on Twitter, and then found out the signing was happening right there, and that it didn’t cost anything. So, of course, I decided to stay since I already had the book in my hands. Why not get it signed?
 
Once done, I went to the MARVEL booth (Booth #2329). Getting access to the booth can be extremely difficult since it is always capped. Usually, people rush to the booth early in the morning when the exhibit hall first opens, causing volunteers to give out cards with a time to come back. However, after talking to a volunteer managing the lines at the booth before The Magicians signing (Boom! Studios was right next to MARVEL), I learned that the ADA line was not always capped; so if I became a “shark”, people who circle the booth over and over waiting to get in line because you’re not allowed to just stand to the side anywhere, or came back later and saw some room in the ADA line I could jump in. I didn’t need a timecard for the ADA line. So, of course, since MARVEL always has some of the hottest exclusives at SDCC with their exclusive shirts, pins, and more, I decided to check back after The Magicians signing. And, what did I see? Lots of extra space in the ADA line!! It took about 45 minutes to get through the line, but that was fine by me since I had no clue what I wanted to buy. Ultimately, I decided to purchase “America’s Ass” and “MARVEL 80 Years” shirts, Avengers pin set, and one blind pack 2-pin set. In the blind pack, I got Doctor Strange and Falcon.
 
 
In the late afternoon, I did The Order signing. Cast members that appeared include Jake Manley, Sarah Grey, Adam DiMarco, Devery Jacobs, Thomas Elms, Louriza Tronco, Katharine Isabelle, Dennis Heaton (creator), and Shelley Eriksen (senior writer/EP).
 
 
Not long after that I did the MARVEL’S Agents of S.H.I.E.L.D. signing. Cast members that appeared include Chloe Bennet, Iain De Caestecker, Natalia Cordova-Buckley, Clark Gregg, Elizabeth Henstridge, Henry Simmons, Jeff Ward and Ming-Na Wen, as well as executive producers Jeff Bell, Jed Whedon, Maurissa Tancharoen and Jeph Loeb.
 
 
Immediately after I finished that autograph signing, I did an interview with 20th Century Fox about the signing. A woman randomly pulled me to the side after I exited the ABC booth and asked if I was up to doing an interview regarding meeting the cast. After being taken to the VIP section (at least that’s what I’m calling it since no regular attendees had access to it), I met the interviewer and camera crew. After reading aloud a liability waiver to the camera, the interviewer began asking me questions. Heart beating out of my chest, excitement pumping through my veins, and hands trembling, I gave fruitful, touching responses to questions like: “What did you just do?”, “How do you feel?”, “Why are you MARVEL’S Agents of S.H.I.E.L.D. biggest fan?”, and “What is the connection between MARVEL and SDCC?” Although intimidating, the entire experience only enhanced my high on euphoria as I was able to share a small part of my experience at SDCC with others.
 
Friday:
 
At 4 a.m., I got in line in the Everything Else line. They let us in around 9:30 the Autograph Area in the Sails Pavilion. On my first try, I drew the winning autograph ticket for The Expanse.
 
Later that morning, I ventured over to artist alley. I had seen a lot of people retweeting and tweeting about artist’s Patrick Ballesteros work, and wanted to see his art prints in person. Finding him at Artist Alley Tale DD-08, I quickly realized how popular he was. His line was capped and there were sharks everywhere, thus making the line forever capped. Between being one of the sharks and waiting in life, it took about an hour for me to purchase what I wanted, which was the “The Fallen” and “The End” art prints. Both prints measure 11” x 14,” are printed on Fine Art Linen Paper, and are signed by the Artist—Patrick Ballesteros (both $25 each). “The Fallen” depicts season eight episode three (“The Battle of Winterfell”), otherwise known as the episode when the Night King attacks on Winterfell. “The End” depicts the movie Avengers: Endgame.
 
 
That afternoon, I did The Expanse signing. Cast members that appeared include Steven Strait, Wes Chatham, Shohreh Aghdashloo, Frankie Adams, Cas Anvar, Dominique Tipper, Naren Shankar, Ty Franck, and Daniel Abraham.
 
 
At 6:00 p.m., I attended the TV Guide Magazine’s annual Fan Favorites Panel in Ballroom 20, which always includes some fun panelists, from some of your favorite series, all in one place. This year, the panel included The Magicians‘ Brittany Curran, Superstore‘s Ben Feldman, The Flash‘s Candice Patton, The 100‘s favorite real-life couple Bob Morley and Eliza Taylor, American Gods‘ Yetide Badaki, Legends of Tomorrow‘s Caity Lotz, The Good Place‘s William Jackson Harper, Legacies‘ Matt Davis, Superstore‘s Lauren Ash, and Marvel’s Agents of S.H.I.E.L.D.‘s Clark Gregg. Arrow’s Stephen Amell also made a special guest appearance at the end of the panel in honor of this year being Arrow’s final Comic-Con. Watching these actors geek out over each other and get really excited was extremely emotional and touching in the best way possible. The entire panel really focused on the celebration and joy of each actress or actor’s work; therefore, being there first-hand to witness that was truly spectacular.
 
 
Saturday:
 
I got in line in the Everything Else line with my friend at 4 am. Like a speed demon, I ‘walked’ to the IDW Publishing booth (Booth #2729) to grab a ticket for the cast of Wynonna Earp signing. Cast members that were scheduled to appear include Melanie Scrofano, Katherine Barrell, Chantel Riley, Greg Lawson, Michael Eklund, Emily Andras, and Beau Smith. However, despite getting to the booth five minutes after it opened, the line had already been capped and all the wristbands (your ticket to the signing) had been given out. Now, I saw no line. That booth was completely empty, which means that almost everyone that got the signing was an exhibitor as there was no way they had handed out 40 tickets in the time span of five minutes. The entire situation was just like Preview Night when I first tried to get MARVEL’S Agents of S.H.I.E.L.D.
 
Not wanting to have nothing, I decided to try for something in the Sails Pavilion. After all, like I said earlier, they wouldn’t start drawing until everyone in the general line to get into the exhibit hall had done so, which usually takes until about 9:30 a.m. So, I immediately left to go line up in the Exclusive Signings line in the Sails Pavilion. After about 20 minutes of waiting, they let us in the Autograph Area in the Sails Pavilion. Unfortunately, I didn’t draw the winning autograph ticket for The Man in the High Castle. However, my friend did and kindly gave me the stamped ticket.
 
Later that morning, my friend and I did the Star Trek’s CBS All Access Transporter Experience Booth. Stepping aboard the U.S.S. Discovery, I traveled to distant and strange lands through an immersive transporter experience. In the transporter, every person was taken to different locations in the Star Trek universe—one such location was amidst a battle. Now, for anyone who visited and completed the Trek transporter experience on the show floor would receive an exclusive, limited quantity Star Trek pin Starfleet Headquarters visitors badge. Moreover, those who completed the experience along with randomly being selected to partake in the virtual reality battle scene on Saturday morning and early afternoon were given the opportunity to meet some of their favorite Star Trek: Discovery or Star Trek: Picard stars at the booth later that day.
 
Afterwards, I did the Star Trek: Picard signing at the CBS booth (Booth #4237). Patrick Stewart was the only cast member in appearance (but that was fine by me—Patrick was more than enough!)
 
Later that afternoon, I did The Rookie signing. Cast members that appeared include Nathan Fillion, Melissa O’Neil, Eric Winter, Titus Making Jr., Alyssa Diaz and Richard T. Jones.
 
 
I also went to The Man in the High Castle signing. Cast members that appeared include Isa Hackett, Daniel Percival, David Scarpa, Rufus Sewell, Joel de la Fuente, Jason O’Mara, Chelah Horsdal, and Frances Turner.
 
 
Sunday:
 
I really didn’t do much on Sunday. I slept in and roamed the exhibit hall but didn’t buy anything since I spent all my money. It was a very laid-back day, which I REALLY did need after running on coffee for four days straight without any sleep and standing in lines 24/7. But, hey, what’s Comic-Con without sleep exhaustion and aching feet?
 
With San Diego Comic Con now once again come and gone, I’m left with a flurry of feelings and a lot of random food bills. But, if you’re debating on whether to attend (and I say trying because badges are extremely hard to obtain), I suggest you partake in Open Registration. Although it is far from guaranteed to walk away with a Comic-Con badge, you never know what could happen—maybe you’ll get lucky! There is so much to do for any type of fan. No matter what you are interested in, you will have an amazing time. I promise you that!

title.rendered: San Diego Comic Con Survival Guide: Part I

content.rendered:
I have attended San Diego Comic Con since 2015. Hence, I have picked up some wisdom about how to survive the five-day madness. For any newbie, Comic-Con can appear intimidating. After all, what exactly does it take to survive the largest show in North America? So, I’ve compiled a list of tips that will ensure you have the best experience possible at the convention.
 
Here are 30 things that everyone, from first-time attendee to veterans, should know before attending San Diego Comic Con:
 
1. I had an ADA sticker (given by the Deaf and Disabled Services), given that I sometimes have issues with my left foot I broke a year ago. That said, ADA has a separate line than general admission when it comes to lining up at a booth, or getting into the exhibit hall, Sails Pavilion, and panels—and their line is way shorter.
 
2. To participate in many of the exclusive signings or merchandise, you must have been selected to participate in a studio or exhibitor exclusive signing via the online exclusives portal (which only attendees have access to)—the process is completely random and your chances of getting anything are slim to none.
 
3. Signings not given out in the lottery are given out by the studio’s booth (typically the day of the signing) or in the Autograph Area in the Sails Pavilion.
 
4. Signings given out by the booth are usually first come, first serve (ABC, IDW, and MARVEL do this!) but not always though—**cough, cough** CBS.
 
5. Signings given out in Sails consists of drawing a ticket out of a bag filled with “loser” and “winner” tickets.
 
6. For any exclusive signing, you should line up about 45 minutes to one hour before the signing begins.
 
7. To get the autographs not given out in the lottery, you must get in line by 4 a.m. (and that’s just for the ADA line). I would guess by 12 a.m. for the regular line.
 
8. To attend AND get a decent seat in any Hall H panel, you must camp out at least a day before the actual panel People camped out for three days this year for the MARVEL panel.
 
9. The biggest panels rooms, where all the large studios have their panels, are Rooms 6A, 6BCF, 6DE, Ballroom 20, Hall H, and the Indigo Ballroom—especially the last three.
 
10. Some after parties cost money, which you must purchase a ticket for ahead of time. It can sometimes be a huge competition to obtain tickets online too as some parties sell out fast.
 
11. Parking is expensive. If you’re parking at a hotel, it costs about $50. If you want something cheaper, you must partake in the lottery-based system for convention parking (which happens about two months before the Comic-Con). If you’re selected, parking then costs around $10 – $30 a day. The price depends on the day and location.
 
12. SDCC offers a free shuttle to area hotels, and the city has the trolley and other public transportation options, but, in my opinion, these means of transportation take too long to get anywhere.
 
13. Off-site events typically take about 30 minutes to 4 hours to get in. It all depends on how popular and engaging each experience is.
 
14. Most popular booths in the exhibit hall are capped before you even reach the booth and that’s if you line up hours early in the Everything Else line to have first access to the exhibit hall when it opens at 9 a.m.
 
15. Your feet will die—and no, I’m not being dramatic. Your feel will feel as though they have a pulse when you collapse in bed every night. Also, talking about beds, you will only sleep for about 5 hours a night, if that. Starbucks is everyone’s best friend at Comic-Con.
 
16. Gaslamp is the best place to grab food. There’s so much going on in that area that you can still feel as though you’re at SDCC when eating. I’m telling you—FOMO is real here.
 
17. EAT AND DRINK WHEN YOU CAN! If you can buy stuff at 7-Eleven or CVS, do! Drinks in the convention center are $4.50! Don’t get me started on a bag of chips. Plus, you never know when your next chance will be when waiting in lines all day and running around from here to there.
 
18. One person can hold 4 spots in line.
 
19. The Everything Else line leads to separate lines later, which includes the exhibit hall, Sails Pavilion, and Ballroom 20. Hall H has its own separate line.
 
20. Bring a portable phone charger! While waiting in line for XXX you’re going to either explore all your social media feeds or live Tweet, Facebook, and/or Instagram. As a result, your battery will rapidly drain and you will no longer be a happy camper.
 
21. Take cash ($5s and $10s are best). You never know when you’ll need it. Plus, some booths charge a small fee if you use a debit/credit card.
 
22. Don’t go to bed after the doors have closed for the day! You will regret it! Go to an after party or bar to revel over the day’s activities. Downtown San Diego does not sleep during Comic-Con. It’s crazy—in the best way!
 
23. Utilize group buying during Returning/Open Registration. This will increase your odds of scoring that golden ticket. Each person who is randomly selected for a registration session can purchase badges for up to three people (including, but not necessarily, for themselves). So, if you’re working in a group of six, and only two people make it through to checkout, everyone gets a badge!
 
24. Follow @SD_Comic_Con, @ParksAndCons, @Comic_Con, @TeamCoco, @nerdist, @syfy, @WarnerBrosTV, @PatrickBallest, @Marvel, @IDWPublishing, @Hasbro, @DarkHorseComics, @TheCW, @BOOMStudios, and @BBCAmerica on Twitter! Also, join all the SDCC Facebook groups so that you can trade/sell/buy any exclusives as well as interact with other attendees. It’s a great way to make new friends!
 
25. Whenever you pass a bathroom, use it! Restrooms are overall scarce. Therefore, you never know when you’ll have the chance to use one again.
 
26. Sunday is the worst day on the convention floor as that day is the lightest on events.
 
27. If you want an artist to commission something for you, ask them via social media, their website, email, etc. ahead of time as most artists only do pre-commissions for SDCC.
 
28. Find roommates to share the cost of the hotel room (or suite). Hotels jack up the price of their rooms during Comic-Con. Rooms can cost anywhere from $250 to $350 per night (if you survive Hotel Apocalypse!).
 
29. Only have one must-see major event a day. After all, it may take all day just to do that one event.
 
30. PLAN! PLAN! PLAN! I can’t stress this enough. Have a backup plan AND a backup to the backup.
 
San Diego Comic Con is an unforgettable once in a lifetime experience. Moreover, I hope you’ll use these tips and tricks to thoroughly enjoy the convention!

After all, what exactly does it take to survive the largest show in North America? So, I’ve compiled a list of tips that will ensure […]

title.rendered: Building A Business The ‘Harry Potter’ Way

content.rendered:
With seven books, eight movies, a spin-off series, three theme parks, and a theatrical play, Harry Potter is arguably one of the most widely known and popular brand names of all time. In fact, the record-breaking series of books and films have made J.K. Rowling the first author billionaire. But if we were to step back twenty years ago, only book nerds had ever heard of the Wizarding World.
 
In the late 1990s, the Harry Potter series began to come out in print with the publication of Harry Potter and the Philosopher’s Stone in 1997. Moreover, as technology steadily advanced throughout the 20th Century, more and more kids began to swap books for televisions and video games. As a result, the children’s publishing industry began to decline. Even worse, in 2000— when the first Harry Potter film began production in the United Kingdom— fantasy films were repeatedly doing poorly at the box office. So, when Harry Potter was pitched to Disney, the company turned down the opportunity to produce the film series.
 
So, how did Harry Potter succeed? How did a children’s fantasy book series about an 11-year-old living under the stairs become a global franchise with an estimated value of $25 billion?
 
Here are 10 business strategies that Harry Potter utilized order to make the jump from book franchise to a global brand:
 
1. Planning
Thinking long-term help you to not only overcome short-term setbacks but dramatically increases the overall success of your brand. By taking the “less is more” approach, you can maximize your profits over a long span of time rather than just make a quick buck in a short period. Focusing on the short-term causes you to compromise your values to obtain what you want, which eliminates the overall lure of your brand.
 
For example, after Warner Brothers acquired the rights to Harry Potter, the franchise took a more “slow but steady” marketing approach to make sure that the children and parents who loved the stories did not feel that Warner Brothers destroyed them. In other words, instead of outpouring tons of pre-movie Harry Potter merchandise to cash in on the already-popular series, the franchise made absolutely sure that they did not overcommericalize so that parents and children would continue to embrace the series.
2. Merchandise
Make sure your brand is appealing for people of all ages. This helps to broaden your target audience; therefore, attracting more customers. To target anyone and everyone, you must give your customers the option to incorporate your brand into every aspect of their lives.
 
For example, Warner Brothers was able to further develop the Harry Potter brand by targeting all age groups through the release of Harry Potter clothes, home decor, and video games, while also establishing three theme park locations and a studio tour. As a result, Potter fans can step into the Wizard World at any time.
 
3. Emotional Involvement
Clever marketing and savvy business practices can only sell a product so long. What makes a business become a phenomenon is the emotional involvement of its consumers. . Therefore, you must create a cohesive brand, despite how many components it has, to invite customers to join the overall experience your brand has to offer.
 
For example, because each Harry Potter book picked up almost exactly where the previous book left off, and each book followed one main story arc with the same core set of characters, the brand was able to create feelings of stability, sustainability, and security with its fans.
4. Online Buzz
Word-of-mouth marketing is one of the most effective ways to boost products and services. This is because the internet is a place where customers can socialize, network and experience your brand in their own ways. Allowing consumers to take control of the conversation on social media and make the brand their own simply creates more attention to your brand; therefore, attracts more customers.
 
For example, instead of trying to shut down countless Harry Potter fan sites, such as MuggleNet and The Leaky Cauldron, which were started by fans as a way to share their opinions, thoughts, and predictions of the series, Warner Brothers left them alone and simply kept a tab on them. Listening to what the communities said, they then used that information to fulfill the needs of those communities.
 
5. Customer Interest
By leaving consumers wanting more, each marketing tactic implemented to promote your brand should build excitement around your business. This will boost sales to the highest level possible.
 
For example, by Warner Brother leaking bits and pieces of information, holding promotional events and contests, and creating a veil of secrecy around the next product to launch, consumers never got bored with the franchise.
 
6. Brand Consistency
Once customers become loyal to a brand, it’s crucial that nothing is done to betray consumers’ loyalties to it. Hence, you must meet consumer expectations, or they’ll turn away from your brand in search of one that does consistently meet their expectations.
 
For example, when faced with opportunities to extend the Harry Potter brand, J.K. Rowling often turned down brand extension proposals, such as refusing to allow Harry Potter to appear on a McDonald’s Happy Meal, in order to maintain consistency and integrity of the Harry Potter brand.
 
7. Customer Engagement
Engaging with your customers in between pre-release parties, casual events, launching new products, etc. strengthens their emotional connection to your brand. You need to strike the correct balance of giving your customers what they want, while still holding some information back to keep them wanting more.
 
For example, by J.K. Rowling replying, tweeting, and retweeting secret fun facts about the Wizard World, she has maintained a strong relationship with her fans. Her heavy involvement with fans has helped her to retain the customers she already has while gaining new ones.
 
8. Risks
Although taking risks can be scary, and often, end in failure, it can also lead to great success. After all, you can’t achieve your dreams by playing it safe. Not only can risk-taking lead to unforeseen opportunities, but it can help you to overcome the fear of failure, make your brand stand out, and teach you crucial lessons that you can later use to strengthen your brand.
 
For example, although people said that kids only would read books with up to 40,000 words, Harry Potter and the Sorcerer’s Stone had 90,000 words in total. Children’s book publishers also said that kids wouldn’t buy hardcovers, yet Warner Brothers made the Harry Potter books into hardcovers. And guess what? Kids still bought the books.
 
9. In-Person Interactions
With modern society so busy and disconnected, people crave for deeper connections. And, in-person conversations in fun, casual settings do exactly that. Plus, hosting an event or throwing a party will set you apart in promoting your business.
 
For example, starting with the release of Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire, release parties were hosted by bookstores for customers to dress up and await the midnight release of the newest book. At these parties, there was candy, posters, face painting, quizzes, readings from old books, and conversations about what may be contained in the next book. Resultantly, these in-person interactions with the brand promoted massive buzz; therefore, more sales.
10. Storytelling
Always tell a great story. Your brand isn’t just a business, but rather a story that never ends. Brand storytelling should capture your customers’ attention, which can be accomplished through your website, the way you package products, and the way you interact with customers.
 
For example, J.K. Rowling quite literally created a complex and magical world of wizardry, with its own society, customs, characters, and language; moreover, is portrayed in every and anything related to Harry Potter.
 
The story of Harry Potter is just as magical as the story of Harry Potter from a branding perspective. While your small business might not reach the multi-billion-dollar brand value that Harry Potter has reached, you can position yourself for long-term, sustainable business growth by applying these strategies to your marketing plan.

excerpt.rendered: With seven books, eight movies, a spin-off series, three theme parks, and a theatrical play, Harry Potter is arguably one of the most widely known and popular brand names of all time. In fact, the record-breaking series of books and films have made J.K. Rowling the first author billionaire. But if we were to step […]

content.rendered:
Instagram has grown to a platform with over one billion users in 2017. Despite  this platform being for great networking, it has much more of an influence over us then we think. It’s like we are carrying a pocket full of dopamine. Many phycologists associate the addiction to alcohol, gambling, and sex to how we treat social media because of the urge to keep scrolling constantly haunting us. So, how do you draw the line between being at peace with yourselve and being active with your online persona? 
 
It’s important to have this discussion because most of us don’t speak up or aren’t aware social media is increasing our levels of depression, anxiety, and loneliness; we blame it on other factors. I was raised in a strict household where family quality time was extremely important. So, during New Year’s Eve when everyone was out partying I felt very alone in a home filled with family scrolling through my phone. Through conversations and maturity, I’ve learned to put my phone down and appreciate what’s in front of me. 
 
Professional Counselor and Ohio-based Talkspace therapist, Dr. Rachel O’Neill, , said  “The more an individual uses social media, the more they tend to detach from everyday life and this detachment might lead to more social media use. Over time, this cycle can lead an individual to rely exclusively on social media as their only form of interaction with others.”
 
If you realize your emotions are being controlled by your social media activity and don’t feel comfortable speaking about it to anyone, here are a few tips: take a “digital detox” (which is my favorite method when I feel stressed and overwhelmed). I delete all my platforms and I like to read a book outside at a park or in the morning.. However, there is no right or wrong way to do a digital detox, do what brings you peace and happiness within. Another tip is being selective of who you follow. When there are a lot of celebrities on your timeline your mind creates these expectations of how you should look or how you should think. In reality, these celebrities are being photoshopped and are having the same emotions as you. Lastly, with this new iPhone update and new apps coming out you can track your weekly time on social media by taking baby steps decreasing your time on platforms so you can create a balance between your online persona and real life.  Dr. O’Neill said, “Focus on the attainment of controlled internet use, and the reduction of psychosocial problems directly and indirectly related to internet dependence.”
 
Social media addiction has been widely studied, and a 2014 meta-analysis on internet addiction suggests that 6% of individuals globally feel a need to stay constantly connected. Apps like Instagram are what keep us tethered to our devices. This data is a reminder that you are not alone and you have someone to talk to, it’s not a silly feeling, but rather a mental health epidemic. Don’t be afraid or embarrsed to speak up about it a lot of your friends will be thankful you did.

Despite  this platform being for great networking, it has much more of an influence over us then we think. It’s like we are carrying a pocket full of dopamine. Many […]

title.rendered: How To Make The Best of Your Summer Before College

content.rendered:
The summer before college is truly the time to live your best life, unwind from stress and make the most of your time before dedicating yourself to the college lifestyle. To help you make the best of your summer before college, here are eight tips for you.
 
1. Spend time with your friends and family: It’s important to try and spend as much time with your friends and family as possible. Once you get to college, you’ll definitely have moments of homesickness especially if you move far away.. Enjoy the moments with your family and friends this summer and make the most of it!
2. Planning For College Is Essential: Although you’re supposed to be enjoying your summer and living your best life, making sure you have everything sorted out for August when you move-into college is very important. Your college is probably sending out important emails, be sure to check those out and stay on top of everything your school has for you to do over the summer.
3. Get a summer job: Thousands of places are hiring and it’s the best way to make some extra cash before heading out to school. It can be anything from being a lifeguard, babysitting, or working in a retail store. Get yourself some summer money!
4. Read. Read. Read!: Even though it’s summer, it’s important to keep your brain busy and active. Once you get to college, you’ll have a lot of material to read and after not reading for some time, you tend to get lazy and leave the important material that you’re supposed to read in-depth for a test or project. Continuous reading is good for the brain and it’ll be a lifesaver once you get to college.
5. Connect with your future roommate: You’ll find out your rooming assignments about a month before you go to college and if you went for a random assignment, it’s crucial that you connect with your roommate. Get to know each other and try and sort out who’s bringing what. You don’t wanna end up both moving into your double room and you both bring a mini fridge and microwave. You probably don’t have space for that so it’s important to communicate.
6. Be realistic with what you pack: You may be moving away from home but that doesn’t mean you should take your whole closet with you to college. Go through your closet and be realistic with your choices. If you haven’t worn a particular shirt in months or maybe even years, you definitely won’t be wearing it at college. Additionally, if it works out for you this way, when you go home for the holidays you can drop clothes off and bring more. Whatever works for you.
7. Be smart with buying textbooks: I know hundreds of people who buy the textbooks for their classes before getting to school and immediately regretted it. There are cheaper alternatives than your schools bookstore and you’ll save hundreds of dollars. Just do your research. Also, If you’re lucky, your professor may give you the PDF file of the textbook (if they wrote it).
8. Enjoy your freedom and have fun: College is a fun time but your main reason for being there is to get an education and it can get really hectic. You’ll definitely have fun but there’s a balance of living your best life and making sure you’re doing your work. Enjoy this summer before college hits you hard.

excerpt.rendered: The summer before college is truly the time to live your best life, unwind from stress and make the most of your time before dedicating yourself to the college lifestyle. To help you make the best of your summer before college, here are eight tips for you.   1. Spend time with your friends and […]

content.rendered:
Everyone had an opinion to share at their workplace after watching Donald Trump take the presidential election. This need to share each other’s views was so intense that it caused a spike in podcasts because it provided people a space to voice their concerns and create force for key issues from criminal justice to mental illness; this platform is the raw truth of politics. Over the course of 2017, over 1,000 podcasts were launched and more than a third of Americans were listening
 
This podcast revolution has been caused by various factors including, easy accessibility to start your own because all you need is recording device and something to talk about. They also bring this sense of authenticity and imagination to storytelling, it’s similar to reading a book your creating the pictures as you listen to the narrative voice in your head.  psychologist Jonathan Haidt said  “The human mind is a story processor, not a logic processor.”. These factors are what distinguish podcasts from streaming media’s, it’s very applicable to who is listening. What’s interesting is Gen-Z and millennials are leading the pack when it comes to listening and sharing podcasts with 80 percent of millennials and 72 percent of Gen-Z sharing podcasts with friends or colleagues.
 
Racism, mental illness, sexuality ,and climate change  are all issues that have found new voices through podcasts. There still hasn’t been enough research done if it will have a genuine impact on political debate but it  definitely has informed and motivated individuals to speak out against injustice and that’s one step forward. My favorite family, Michelle and Barack Obama, have recently announced their own partnership deal with Spotify to host a Podcast. The Obamas will produce and develop storytelling, with the purpose of being able to inspire people and make the world listen to underrepresented populations, rather than strictly engaging with them politically.
 
“We’re thrilled to have the opportunity to amplify voices that are too often ignored or silenced altogether, and through Spotify, we can share those stories with the world,” Michelle Obama said. “Our hope is that through compelling, inspirational storytelling, Higher Ground Audio will not only produce engaging podcasts, but help people connect emotionally and open up their minds — and their hearts.”
 
The Obamas podcast is one of  thousands you have the option to listen to. There are also dozens of topics for different groups of people and if you can’t find one that catches your attention go grab your recording device and make one! My personal favorite is on Spotify titled “Ear Hustle” because it’s about the daily realities of life inside prison, shared  by those living it, and stories from the outside post-incarceration. Grab your headphones on your way to work or when your at the gym and enjoy a podcast.

content.rendered:
Over the years, June has become associated with rainbow flags, pride parades, and LGBTQ+ rights. Otherwise known as Pride Month. Every June, the LGBTQ+ community honors the 1969 Stonewall Uprising, a series of violent riots between police and gay rights activists outside a gay bar in Manhattan, recognizing the impact LGBTQ+ individuals have had on history — internationally, nationally, and locally.
 
Only twenty years ago, many businesses opposed gay rights. Yet, now corporations cannot wait to market their goods to the LGBTQ+ community. For example, Express Target has “Love Unites” clothing, Bath & Body Works has “Love is Here” candles, hand soaps, and lotions, and Nike has “Be True” sneakers. The list is endless. Countless storefronts are filled with rainbow-colored displays now. From clothes emblazoned with “Love Is Love”, to commercials incorporating slogans of the LGTBQ+ rights movement, everyone is encouraged to celebrate the queer community. So, what changed in the past two decades?
 
Throughout the years, general support for LGBTQ+ rights have grown; thus, becoming extremely profitable. As a result, the corporate incentive for brands to align themselves with these beliefs has increased as well. From celebrations including picnics, workshops, parades, parties, and concerts, Pride Month events attract millions of people. And, of course, people want to partake in the celebrations by buying countless products to show their support or proudly represent their queer community. As a result, businesses always ramp up their LGBTQ+ advertising at the end of May and during June.
 
Pride Month has come to be known as the month where businesses push their LGBTQ+ themed marketing campaigns. But, do brands genuinely support the LBGTQ+ community or are they just rainbow-washing? Unless companies have shown real actions of being an ally, such as donating money to the LGBTQ+ movement, rainbow-washing is simply an attempt to make a quick buck.
 
Many corporations, governments, and people now pretend to support and care about the queer community so that they can either make money and/or fit in with society. After all, it has become the social norm for the younger generations to participate in Pride Month. However, the truth is that many companies do not do any tangible work to support LGBTQ+ communities at any time during the year, including June. Slapping a rainbow on top of something does not make anyone or company an allyship.
 
Atlanta’s rainbow crosswalk is a perfect example of rainbow-washing. Although the crosswalk is absolutely ravishing to look at, the project called for a great deal of money. Costing $196,000, the project commemorated not only Atlanta’s LGBTQ+ history but to honor the individuals who lost their lives during the 2016 Pulse shooting. However, given the choice, would Atlanta’s LGBTQ+ communities have wanted the city to do this with those funds? Most likely not. Instead, this money could have been donated to impactful organizations, used to fight for protections and policies and affecting the queer community, to support local LGBTQ+ community centers, and/or to support homeless LGBTQ+ youth.
 
Then again, is rainbow-washing all bad? Although the support is rooted in the wrong idea, is has yielded certain benefits like visibility. Businesses show their support even if they have ulterior motives for doing so. They may not have to tangibly, but they can show it visibly. Having rainbows plastered everywhere from storefronts to lamp posts is something that was denied to LGBTQ+ folks for hundreds of years. Consequently, compared to 10 or 20 years ago, it is a much easier place for LGBTQ+ individuals to live. That one rainbow flag in a commercial could easily convince someone struggling with their identity to live another day. This raises the question: Are there limitations of symbolic gestures?
 
When it comes to Pride, there is much disconnect in commercialization. Commerce starts to become grey when brands promote and capitalize on the LGBTQ+ community, despite the companies not, or inconsistently, supporting the queer community.
 
If a brand sells Pride merchandise and then gives those profits to a LGBTQ+ organization, such as the Trevor Project, and does not discriminate against LGBTQ+ employees, the company genuinely supports and recognizes LGBTQ+ people. On the other hand, if a company only changes its logo on social media and has rainbow decorations in its store, it can be assumed that the corporation does not truly care about the LGBTQ+ community. They just use rainbows to encourage queers to buy products from them. Is that okay? No. Should companies be held to a higher standard of allyship? Yes.
 
But, should people, such as the individuals who tag along to parades, be held to a higher standard of allyship? If that people’s only “genuine” intent to support, should they be wearing any kind of rainbow object at all? In the past few years, it appears that anything with a rainbow on it has come to represent the LGBTQ+ community. And, unfortunately, many people now feel as though they are fighting for LGBTQ+ rights just from when wearing a rainbow when all they are doing is bringing awareness around the issues that affect the queer community.
 
The truth is the only thing these people are doing are spreading awareness. But, what LGBTQ+ individuals need is action. Companies that donate a portion of their Pride merchandise profits to organizations working to promote equality, provide access to education and healthcare, and eliminate discrimination are helping. For example, J. Crew donates 50% of the profits made from its Pride T-shirts and H&M donates 10% of their sales from its “Pride Out Loud” collection. Although billions of dollars spent on rainbow merchandise raise money for a charitable cause, the likelihood of any major, tangible change coming about is slim.
 
Customers who want to do more to help the LGBTQ+ community do not have to just wear rainbow-themed merchandise. If people truly care, they can question what companies are doing with the money profited from “Pride” products or those companies’ inconsistent policies. Scrutinizing brands, especially on social media as such conflicts can easily gain the public’s attention, could help change the way companies choose to “support” LGBTQ+ individuals. The difference between this and raising awareness is that online trolling causes businesses to gain a bad reputation. When in this situation, brands must act to satisfy their customers’ needs. If they do not, the bad publicity will negatively affect their sales, cause customers to lose trust in them, and damage brand association.
 
For too long, companies have taken advantage of a community they have historically and often presently neglect, harm, and ignore. Often, the money that numerous brands do not donate to charities is used to fund the Republican Party, a conservative organization that has shown with Trump’s presidency that it does not support the LGBTQ+ community.
 
Although it is amazing brands are smothering a homophobic world with countless symbols of LGBTQ+ support and love, brands need to start putting their mouth where their marketing is. Corporations have the power and wealth to make a real difference, yet they continue to merely include a few pride hashtags on their social media accounts and follow rainbow-color schemes. Nevertheless, make sure that whenever you buy Pride merchandise from a company that its goal is to promote the rights of the queer community through awareness and funding supporting organizations. Sometimes you must do research to make sure a brand’s support is not merely superficial. Otherwise, you are just enabling these brands to exploit Pride month.

excerpt.rendered: Over the years, June has become associated with rainbow flags, pride parades, and LGBTQ+ rights. Otherwise known as Pride Month. Every June, the LGBTQ+ community honors the 1969 Stonewall Uprising, a series of violent riots between police and gay rights activists outside a gay bar in Manhattan, recognizing the impact LGBTQ+ individuals have had on […]

title.rendered: Let’s Talk About She’s Gotta Have It: An Attack on Black British People?

content.rendered:
Spike Lee’s Netflix series, She’s Gotta Have It has been the topic of discussion due to comments said on the show. For those of you who don’t know; She’s Gotta Have It is an American comedy-drama television series. It is based on Lee’s 1986 film of the same name. The series follows a carefree, sexually liberated black woman named Nola Darling who is living in Brooklyn and navigating her personal and professional life.
In the fifth episode, we see Nola in conversation with her new love interest Olu – a British Nigerian sculptor. The pair discuss how Black Britons are taking jobs from African Americans actors.
 
In the episode, it was suggested by Olu, that Black British actors were better suited to U.S roles because they are free from the psychological burden of “Black History” after Nola said, “You London blokes need to fall back and fall away from taking all of our roles. We have dope, talented, trained, qualified black actors right here in the States. And at the end of the day, black Brits just come cheaper.” Nola responds to Olu explaining, “British ships were the dominant force in the Atlantic slave trade. Almost two million kidnapped Africans died. So you and your fellow Black British blokes didn’t come out unscathed. You just have Stockholm syndrome and fell in love with your captors.” In addition to these comments, Nola also deliberately mispronounces British actors, John Boyega’s and Chiwetel Ejiofor’s names who are both of Nigerian descent.
 
This clip caused a lot of outrage from Black Britons and more. Famous British-Nigerian actor, John Boyega reacted to the clip and called it, “Trash.”
 
First and foremost, lots of people are angry at Spike Lee. Hundreds of people call the dialogue in the episode, ignorant, racist and xenophobic. British director, Alegria Adedeji who posted the clip and openly criticised the show mentions in an interview that “it’s really disheartening. It chips away at the validity of the experience of black British people. To then liken our relationship with the British Empire to that of Stockholm Syndrome is not only grossly offensive, but it’s scarily inaccurate and ahistorical.” The dialogue in She’s Gotta Have It suggests that only Black Americans have had some sense of struggle and that Black Britons will never understand. Spike Lee uses his platform to perform an erasure of Black Britons’ history of slavery, colonialism and enduring modern day racism that limit their economic opportunities.
 
As someone who has many intersections to their identity, me being American-British Nigerian, I was highly offended by this part of the show that went viral on Twitter as were my friends and family as well as thousands of other people. Although born and raised in the US for a number of years, my adolescent years were spent in the UK before moving back to the US for university. I’d like to think, due to the fact that I grew up there from the ages of 12 to 18, I have a stronger relationship with my British identity more than my American. Additionally, I’m also Nigerian and the deliberate butchering of John Boyega and Chiwetel Ejiofor’s names is something a lot of Nigerians can relate to if they went to school in the West or even in the workplace. There’s already animosity between Africans and African Americans and that deliberate butchering furthers this. Now, the narrative of black Britons “taking” jobs from African-Americans is something that should be discussed and have space, but the way in which it was dealt with through this series and comments in the past from Spike Lee makes it seem like an “assault to black British people” as said by Alegria Adedeji. As a community, one must understand that there is validity to discussions that regard this issue but working in an industry where film executives already have limited roles for black people across the board, why divide us even more?
 
As mentioned before, there is a valid conversation regarding this topic but the way it is being addressed through this show and ignorant comments is not the right way. Will there ever be a time where this can be discussed or will it remain a game of struggle between the two entities?

For those of you who don’t know; She’s Gotta Have It is an American comedy-drama television series. It is based on Lee’s 1986 film of the same name. The series follows a carefree, sexually […]

content.rendered:
Marvel Entertainment is arguably one of the most recognized brand names in the world. Yet, step back ten years ago, many people had never heard of Marvel.
 
In 1996, Marvel had to file for bankruptcy protection to stop the company going under. As a result, X-Men and Fantastic Four were sold off to 20th Century Fox and Spider-Man was sold off to Sony Pictures. Although Bryan Singer’s X-Men and Sam Raimi’s Spider-Man relaunches brought in millions of dollars, Marvel only saw a very small amount of that money.
 
In 2003, talent agent David Maisel pitched Marvel the idea to create their own production studio and write and produce these titles in house so that they could keep all of the profits.
 
In 2005, Maisel’s plan was approved. This resulted in a $525 million, seven-year deal with Merrill Lynch. Consequently, Marvel Studios, an internal production company that would give Marvel complete creative control over their films, would be launched. However, to receive that $525 million, Marvel had to put up their remaining properties, including Captain America, Ant-Man, Doctor Strange, Hawkeye, The Avengers, Black Panther, Power Pack, Cloak & Dagger, Shang-Chi, and Nick Fury, up as collateral. In other words, if Marvel failed, they would lose the rights to all ten of those properties.
 
So, how did Marvel succeed? How did the franchise become so widely known and popular? Two words: brand marketing.
 
Branding is crucial for any business to become successful. Brand identity must be baked into everything a company produces as excellent branding leads to more customers and profits. Most importantly, it increases a company’s value. Marvel has become arguably one of the most recognized brand names universally. Marvel has built worlds with content, which is why any marketer could learn a thing or two from the Marvel Cinematic Universe (MCU).
 
In the beginning of the Marvel Cinematic Universe, with a proprietary library of over 8,000 characters, focused on lesser-known characters such as Thor, Iron Man, and Captain America. As crazy as it sounds, these characters were not nearly as popular as they are now. Struggling to compete with DC Entertainment and not wanting to go head-to-head with the likes of Batman and Superman, Marvel gradually began to build an unshakeable brand.
 
Instead of throwing tactic after tactic at the wall in the hopes that something would stick, Marvel strategically created a consistent movie going experience that engaged their audience. Additionally, Marvel developed a new unique look, feel, tone, and voice of their movies by showcasing more well-humored, relatable, and action-oriented stories.
 
Gradually, Marvel built the profile of individual heroes, including Iron Man, the Hulk, Thor, and Captain America, while teasing plotlines to come. And of course, audiences embraced these relatively known characters because they were relatable.
 
Instead of Marvel throwing all these individual heroes into The Avengers and making quick money, the franchise created character-driven movies to help the audience get up close and personal with each character. Of course, each movie leading up to The Avengers was designed to make money, but they were also designed to attract a much larger audience for The Avengers. After all, the buzz around each hero individually forced the audience to fall in love with each character by the time The Avengers hit theaters.
 
By Marvel nurturing their audience, the franchise earned their customers’ trust that they would have a positive experience buying from their company. This has allowed Marvel to increase their brand awareness, leading to massive box office sales for later movies and more earnings from merchandising of all characters.
 
As a result of the success of The Avengers, each Avenger got another individual movie to further develop his/her character; of course, earning more money. At this point, Marvel’s audience became attracted to all of their marketing communications channels, also sometimes referred to as media channels, no matter who the characters were or the particular media channel. From traditional media, including television, print publications, events, physical advertisements, and radio to digital marketing channels, including websites, blogs, podcasts, social media, videos, and mobile, Marvel had countless “vehicles” to distribute their messages to their target audience and create a stronger relationship with them.
 
Inside theaters, Marvel began to capitalize on their groundwork by introducing lesser known characters. For example, the franchise turned Ant-Man, The Guardians of the Galaxy, Doctor Strange, and Black Panther—four previously lesser-known comics series—into crucial, multi-billion-dollar franchises.
 
Outside theaters, Marvel began to slowly incorporate existing characters and fleshing out the Avengers’ story by highlighting minor characters. For example, the franchise turned TV shows like Agents of SHIELD (2013 – Present), Agent Carter (2015 – 2016), and Inhumans (2017) into popular ABC series and Cloak & Dagger (2018 – Present) into a popular Freeform series.
 
Expanding the Marvel universe on the streaming platform, Daredevil (2015 – 2018) was created for Netflix. After the series proved to be successful, Jessica Jones (2015 – 2019), Luke Cage (2016 – 2018), The Punisher (2017 – 2019), and Iron Fist (2017 – 2018), and The Defenders (2018) all were launched. Taking on Hulu, Runaways (2017 – Present), Ghost Rider, and Helstrom. The Falcon and the Winter Soldier, What If…?, WandaVision, Loki, and an untitled Hawkeye series, are set to premiere on Disney’s very own streaming service, Disney+, which launches on November 12, 2019 in the U.S.
 
Without each of these movies and TV shows, fans may have never heard of Ant-Man, Jessica Jones, and Luke Cage. And, because it is entirely possible that fans had never heard of these minor heroes before, such characters would have never been able to carry shows or movies without the support of the overall MCU.
 
Throughout these expansions, Marvel makes it abundantly clear that the universe is the same. Captain America appears briefly in Ant-Man, Nick Fury is in several films, the Hulk in Thor: Ragnarok, Doctor Strange in Thor: Ragnarok, and Iron Man in Spider-Man: Homecoming. The Netflix shows reference “the incident” that occurred in the movies, as well as each other. By making references to each other, the movies and shows can stand alone while maintaining continuity.
 
Furthermore, every movie in the MCU, beginning with Iron Man, contains at least one scene after the credits roll. These post-credit scenes introduce the concept of Marvel’s shared movie universe. Not only do these post-credit scenes strengthen fans’ connection to Marvel, but they help deepen Marvel’s overall brand. Viewers have come to expect a post-credits sequence whenever they watch a Marvel film. Moreover, they also build anticipation and promote subsequent films in the franchise while fostering a feeling of exclusivity among fans who saw the movie and credits in the theaters.
 
Marvel has two audiences they must reach: comics readers and non-comics readers. Since the characters were not built from scratch, Marvel has leaned onto its almost 60 years of source material to not only bring the best of their stories into their films, but to bring nostalgia to the legendarily loyal and obsessive fanboys and girls. Sometimes dialogue was taken directly from the comics.
 
To lure the new blood, Marvel knew it would need to make these movies accessible to viewers who had no knowledge of the comics’ established world as well. As a result, Marvel launched Volume 4 of Hawkeye shortly after The Avengers was released as a way of capitalizing on the character’s appearance in the movie and to keep Hawkeye in the public eye. In addition, Marvel launched Marvel NOW Guardians of the Galaxy comic book series around the time casting announcements were being made for Guardians of the Galaxy. Lastly, Marvel introduced Fear Itself, comics focused on Thor, Captain America, and Iron Man, shortly before Thor and Captain America: The First Avenger were released.
 
To further attract new fans, Marvel began partaking in conventions, which includes parties, panels, autographs, photo-ops, vendors, and other events. Stimulating feelings of exclusivity, like the emotions the post-credit scenes evoke, Comic Cons provide Marvel easy access to their die-hard fans. The Comic-Con experience presents pieces of content, such as the release of a new movie trailer or pre-screening, that sparks conversation among fans until that content is officially released to the general public.
 
As Marvel continues to serve their ever-growing fanbase, they are slowly becoming a lifestyle brand. Now that Marvel is working with other brands, fans are now seeing an increase in variety, content, and quality coming from Marvel digital. For example, in 2016, Marvel partnered with Coca-Cola on its Super Bowl commercial. Marvel also partnered with Audi to create an advertisement to promote Captain America: Civil War. Additionally, Marvel partnered with Ford to promote Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 2. Producing a commercial to advertise the car and briefly including it in the movie, the Ford EcoSport became the “official” vehicle for the Guardians of the Galaxy. These ads are ultimately driven by storytelling, which is why fans are so happy to consume it. Often, they do not even realize they are ads since the promotions provide fans more knowledge about Marvel’s characters and stories.
 
Marvel Cinematic Universe has found a formula that works. After all, producing the Infinity series is one of the most ambitious media projects ever attempted. Analyzing how Marvel bounced back from bankruptcy to becoming Hollywood’s biggest brand can offer an insight into messaging in entertainment advertising and brand consistency.
 
If brands can learn anything from the successes of the Marvel Cinematic Universe, it is that they need to consider the practicality of keeping audiences on the hook for a long-term campaign. Marvel teaches marketers that each triumph only makes your brand stronger. A strong brand makes everything your company does easier. It makes small wins possible and big wins bigger.
 
Forging a personal connection, utilizing your existing assets, understanding your audience, thinking holistically, and going with the flow all make your brand stand out. Also, simply being different from others and embracing that difference, leverage your brand’s history, and having powerful storytelling can allow your brand to flourish. Most importantly, trust Marvel: good branding will pay off in the long run.

excerpt.rendered: Marvel Entertainment is arguably one of the most recognized brand names in the world. Yet, step back ten years ago, many people had never heard of Marvel.   In 1996, Marvel had to file for bankruptcy protection to stop the company going under. As a result, X-Men and Fantastic Four were sold off to 20th […]

content.rendered:
I always knew I wanted to be a journalist. I loved being able to tell stories that could inspire others and possibly change the world. However, as I got older, I realized that there will be many barriers that will try to stop me from achieving my dream as a Latina. In the journalism field, about 7.4% of the newsroom are women and if you categorize by race less than 5% are women of color. These statistics have only encouraged me to work harder but, I know how discouraging it could be for other women.
 
A method I use to keep myself motivated  is reading the stories of other Latina journalists like Maria Hinojosa. Born in Mexico but raised in Chicago, Maria always felt a deep connection with her culture so, she made the decision to not become a U.S citizen until she was 30 years old. Maria attended Barnard College, part of the Columbia University system with the intention of pursuing acting but it became  difficult for anyone to cast her because she was Latina. Therefore, she decided to take a different route as a producer and radio host..the rest was history. Maria Hinojosa has reported for CBS, CNN, PBS, and NPR. She anchored the Frontline report “Lost in Detention,”and she is the host of the Peabody Award-winning NPR show Latino USA.
 
During an interview with the Women’s Media Center, Maria said, “When journalists feel really comfortable in their skin, and their workplaces encourage them to get in touch with their own journalistic passions — and we are not easy about the news; this is a tough group — they know they’ve as much right as anyone else to pitch a story.” Reading about Latina women who had the same dream and were able to accomplish it, motivates me because they are living proof.
 
According to the writer Claire Lampen, she claims the news industry hiring process has not been evolving but rather taking steps back and women in the news room only keep decreasing. PBS host and Today show veteran Ann Curry said, “Men tend to groom men … who [often] are like themselves, in height, coloring, and even demeanor.” Most newsrooms  were owned by white men so, those who fit that criteria are still more likely to get the job regardless of qualifications.
 
I remember telling my mom I wanted to be a journalist like it was yesterday,   and her explaining all the sacrifices this field would require from me. I would have to work ten times harder than everyone else to prove I belong in the newsroom.
 
Will Smith once said, “The separation of talent and skill is one of the greatest misunderstood concepts for people who are trying to excel, who have dreams, who want to do things. Talent you have naturally. Skill is only developed by hours and hours and hours of beating on your craft.” This concept is instilled within me. Without hard work I wouldn’t have been able to proudly say I am interning at the New York Senator Jim Gaughran; and this is only the beginning of my journey.
 
I’ve made it this far all these years because I always had women to look up to. My number one role model is my mother, she began as a maid in a hotel and now she is the boss. In every field women of color will never be the first option,  and it can be overwhelming when reading the numbers to back up this data but it’s our responsibility to break these barriers for our daughters.
